p: Ensure that the account administration interface is separate from the main application interface.

Account administration requires higher privileges than the main application interface. Separating the two interfaces decreases the risk that a normal user will be able to escalate privileges to that of an administrator.
To verify that the account administration interface is separate from the main application interface:
Verify that your application has a separate administrative interface. Review your application's design and verify that it passes the following checks:
Ensure that the administrative interface is secure. Examine the security of your application's administrative interface:

Only privileged users can administer all accounts. Design
 your application such that the administrative module is separate from 
the main application interface. Since the separation requires using 
separate authentication mechanisms for the application and 
administration, there is a reduced risk of escalation-of-privilege 
attacks.

Users may be allowed to administer their own accounts. It
 may be necessary to allow users to administer their own accounts. This 
involves the ability to change passwords, account details, etc. Such 
administration can be done through the main application interface. 
Because the user is modifying sensitive data, extra security precautions
 must be enforced:
ol:
Verify that your application has a separate administrative interface. Review your application's design and verify that it passes the following checks:
      
        
          Administrative Functionality: Verify that all administrative functionality is clearly identified and separate from the rest of your application's functionality. Exceptions are allowed only when your application allows users to modify their own accounts.
        
          Code Organization: Ensure all administrative functionality is structured as a single module and not scattered throughout your application.
      
    
    
      
        Ensure that the administrative interface is secure. Examine the security of your application's administrative interface:
      
        
          Security Policy: Ensure that your application has a security policy regarding its administrative interface.
        
          Separate Authentication: Verify that privileged users are forced to re-authenticate before accessing the administrative interface. Check if your application's administrative interface uses a separate authentication module from the rest of your application.
        
          Access Controls: Verify that only valid, privileged users can access your application's administrative interface.
        
          Connection: Depending on your application's requirements, it may be necessary to check if your application's administrative interface is utilizing TLS. Ensure your application's proper use of TLS.

Only privileged users can administer all accounts. Design
 your application such that the administrative module is separate from 
the main application interface. Since the separation requires using 
separate authentication mechanisms for the application and 
administration, there is a reduced risk of escalation-of-privilege 
attacks.
    
    
      
        Users may be allowed to administer their own accounts. It
 may be necessary to allow users to administer their own accounts. This 
involves the ability to change passwords, account details, etc. Such 
administration can be done through the main application interface. 
Because the user is modifying sensitive data, extra security precautions
 must be enforced:
      
        
          Track userID at the server-side: The user 
should always be tracked at the server-side. Store the userID inside a 
session. The only data the client needs to know is the session 
identifier. This reduces the risk of an attacker modifying another 
user's account information.
        
          Force re-authentication: Enforce 
re-authentication when modifying the user's password. This helps verify 
that the user is aware of the password change and is not a victim of a 
session hijacking. Consult the Force Re-Authentication When Executing Critical Functionality guideline for more details.
        
          Modify accounts in sections: Do not modify 
all account information at once. Split the account modification 
procedure in sections. For example, group the account information into 
credentials, personal data, contact information and additional 
information. Modifying the account information in groups reduces the 
risk of information leakage when the user is updating his/her account.
        
          Use TLS when modifying accounts: The use of 
TLS provides encryption when transmitting sensitive data over the 
network. TLS also certifies the authenticity of the application against 
the user. Consult the Use TLS When Transmitting Credentials guideline for more details.

a: Force Re-Authentication When Executing Critical Functionality

links.text: Force Re-Authentication When Executing Critical Functionality

html:
Applies to

Scala and Play Framework 2.1.0+

What to Check For

Ensure that the account administration interface is separate from the main application interface.

Why

Account administration requires higher privileges than the main application interface. Separating the two interfaces decreases the risk that a normal user will be able to escalate privileges to that of an administrator.

How to Check

To verify that the account administration interface is separate from the main application interface:

  1. Verify that your application has a separate administrative interface. Review your application's design and verify that it passes the following checks:

    • Administrative Functionality: Verify that all administrative functionality is clearly identified and separate from the rest of your application's functionality. Exceptions are allowed only when your application allows users to modify their own accounts.
    • Code Organization: Ensure all administrative functionality is structured as a single module and not scattered throughout your application.

  2. Ensure that the administrative interface is secure. Examine the security of your application's administrative interface:

    • Security Policy: Ensure that your application has a security policy regarding its administrative interface.
    • Separate Authentication: Verify that privileged users are forced to re-authenticate before accessing the administrative interface. Check if your application's administrative interface uses a separate authentication module from the rest of your application.
    • Access Controls: Verify that only valid, privileged users can access your application's administrative interface.
    • Connection: Depending on your application's requirements, it may be necessary to check if your application's administrative interface is utilizing TLS. Ensure your application's proper use of TLS.

How to Fix

When designing an administrative interface:

  1. Only privileged users can administer all accounts. Design your application such that the administrative module is separate from the main application interface. Since the separation requires using separate authentication mechanisms for the application and administration, there is a reduced risk of escalation-of-privilege attacks.

  2. Users may be allowed to administer their own accounts. It may be necessary to allow users to administer their own accounts. This involves the ability to change passwords, account details, etc. Such administration can be done through the main application interface. Because the user is modifying sensitive data, extra security precautions must be enforced:

    • Track userID at the server-side: The user should always be tracked at the server-side. Store the userID inside a session. The only data the client needs to know is the session identifier. This reduces the risk of an attacker modifying another user's account information.
    • Force re-authentication: Enforce re-authentication when modifying the user's password. This helps verify that the user is aware of the password change and is not a victim of a session hijacking. Consult the Force Re-Authentication When Executing Critical Functionality guideline for more details.
    • Modify accounts in sections: Do not modify all account information at once. Split the account modification procedure in sections. For example, group the account information into credentials, personal data, contact information and additional information. Modifying the account information in groups reduces the risk of information leakage when the user is updating his/her account.
    • Use TLS when modifying accounts: The use of TLS provides encryption when transmitting sensitive data over the network. TLS also certifies the authenticity of the application against the user. Consult the Use TLS When Transmitting Credentials guideline for more details.
